items.standfirst: Donald Trump announces all hostages will be released ‘very soon’ and Israel will withdraw troops to an agreed timelineGaza ceasefire plan – live updatesWhat we know so far about the dealIsrael and Hamas have agreed to the initial phase of a ceasefire plan in Gaza, pausing hostilities in the devastated territory and bringing the best hope yet of a definitive end to a bloody two-year conflict that has killed tens of thousands, destabilised much of the Middle East and prompted protests around the world.Donald Trump announced the agreement on his Truth Social network saying all of the hostages held in Gaza would be released soon and Israel would withdraw troops to an agreed line as the first step to a “Strong, Durable, and Everlasting Peace”. News reports indicate a deal has been reached between Israel and Hamas.
The Israeli Consul General in New York reacted to the ceasefire agreement.
Families of hostages gathered in Tel Aviv after the announcement of the deal.

items.content: A French court increases by a year the jail term of the only man who challenged his conviction for raping Gisèle Pelicot.

items.title: Only man to appeal Gisele Pelicot rape conviction handed longer sentence

items.content: A French appeals court has handed a longer 10-year sentence to the only man to challenge his conviction for raping Gisele Pelicot while she was drugged and unconscious.

items.title: French appeal court increases sentence of Gisèle Pelicot rapist
items.standfirst: Husamettin Dogan loses appeal after jury at retrial finds him guilty of raping Pelicot while she was sedatedA man has been found guilty on appeal of raping Gisèle Pelicot after she was drugged unconscious by her husband – and has had his prison sentence increased to 10 years.Husamettin Dogan, 44, an unemployed builder, who had contested his first conviction last year, faced a retrial this week at Nîmes court of appeal. Continue reading...
items.content: Husamettin Dogan loses appeal after jury at retrial finds him guilty of raping Pelicot while she was sedatedA man has been found guilty on appeal of raping Gisèle Pelicot after she was drugged unconscious by her husband – and has had his prison sentence increased to 10 years.Husamettin Dogan, 44, an unemployed builder, who had contested his first conviction last year, faced a retrial this week at Nîmes court of appeal. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A French appeals court increased Husamettin Dogan's sentence to ten years.
Dogan was convicted of raping Gisele Pelicot after she was drugged.
The court's decision followed Dogan's appeal of his initial conviction.
Dogan was the only person to challenge his conviction for the rape.
The retrial took place at the Nîmes court of appeal this week.

items.standfirst: Former UK prime minister told post-ministerial jobs watchdog roles would not involve lobbying or UK policy influenceRishi Sunak has been appointed as a senior adviser by the US technology companies Microsoft and Anthropic.The former British prime minister’s pair of new jobs emerged on Thursday in letters published by Westminster’s office of the Advisory Committee on Business Appointments (Acoba). They add to his roles as a senior adviser to Goldman Sachs International, the investment bank, and speechmaker to investment firms including Bain Capital and Makena Capital in the US, which have netted him over £150,000 a talk. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
clusters.neutral_headline: Discord Says Hackers Stole Government IDs of 70,000 Users

items.title: Discord says hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users
items.standfirst: As more sites require IDs for user age verification, expect more such breaches to come.
items.content: Discord says that hackers made off with images of 70,000 users’ government IDs that they were required to provide in order to use the site. Like an increasing number of sites, Discord requires certain users to provide a photo or scan of their driver's license or other government ID that shows they meet the minimum age requirements in their country. In some cases, Discord allows users to prove their age by providing a selfie that shows their faces (it’s not clear how a face proves someone’s age, but there you go). The social media site imposes these requirements on users who are reported by other users to be under the minimum age for the country they’re connecting from. “A substantial risk for identity theft” On Wednesday, Discord said that ID images of roughly 70,000 users “may have had government-ID photos exposed” in a recent breach of a third-party service Discord entrusted to manage the data. The affected users had communicated with Discord’s Customer Support or Trust & Safety teams and subsequently submitted the IDs in reviews of age-related appeals.Read full article Comments

items.title: Discord says 70,000 photo IDs compromised in customer service breach
items.standfirst: No word on why the outsourced supplier was storing this data in the first place Communication platform provider Discord has admitted that around 70,000 users had their government IDs stolen as part of its recent data breach.…
items.content: No word on why the outsourced supplier was storing this data in the first place Communication platform provider Discord has admitted that around 70,000 users had their government IDs stolen as part of its recent data breach.…

items.title: ID photos of 70,000 users may have been leaked, Discord says
items.standfirst: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.
items.content: The platform says hackers targeted a firm that helped to verify the ages of its users.

ai_summary: Discord reported that hackers stole government IDs of 70,000 users.
The breach occurred through an outsourced customer service supplier.
The platform is used for age verification, requiring IDs.
The company did not specify why the supplier stored the data.
The incident highlights the risk of data breaches with ID requirements.

items.title: Texas Court Blocks Execution of Robert Roberson in Landmark 'Shaken Baby' Case
items.standfirst: Texas' highest criminal court has stayed the execution of Robert Roberson, a death row inmate who was—for the second time in two years—less than a week away from becoming the first person in the country to be executed based on evidence of what used to be called "shaken baby syndrome." In a…
items.content: Texas' highest criminal court has stayed the execution of Robert Roberson, a death row inmate who was—for the second time in two years—less than a week away from becoming the first person in the country to be executed based on evidence of what used to be called "shaken baby syndrome." In a…

ai_summary: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals blocked Robert Roberson's execution.
The court agreed to reopen Roberson's habeas petition.
Roberson was scheduled to be executed in one week.
The case involves "shaken baby syndrome" evidence.
This is the second time in two years the execution was blocked.

clusters.title: Man rearrested at Manchester airport after synagogue attack detention
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Re-arrested at Airport After Synagogue Attack Detention

items.title: Man rearrested at Manchester airport after synagogue attack detention
items.standfirst: Counter-terror police arrest 30-year-old man on suspicion of failing to disclose information about potential terrorist actsA 30-year-old man arrested over the Manchester synagogue attack has been re-arrested at an airport shortly after being released.Counter-terror police detained the man at Manchester airport on Thursday on suspicion of failing to disclose information about potential terrorist acts. The arrest came within 24 hours of the man being released from custody, where he had been held since the attack at Heaton Park synagogue on Yom Kippur last Thursday. Continue reading...

The arrest came within 24 hours of the man being released from custody, where he had been held since the attack at Heaton Park synagogue on Yom Kippur last Thursday. Continue reading...

items.title: László Krasznahorkai wins the Nobel prize in literature 2025
items.standfirst: Hungarian novelist celebrated for dystopian, melancholic novels that ‘reaffirm the power of art’The Nobel prize in literature for 2025 has been awarded to the Hungarian author László Krasznahorkai, the Swedish Academy has announced.The academy cited the 71-year-old’s “compelling and visionary oeuvre that, in the midst of apocalyptic terror, reaffirms the power of art”.To explore all books by László Krasznahorkai, visit guardianbookshop.com. Delivery charges may apply. Continue reading...

Delivery charges may apply. Continue reading...

items.title: The 10th and final escapee from a New Orleans jailbreak is captured after five months
